entry.string:
# this box you can run by option clicking on it, here's the code
def start(): print "Starting..."
def keepGoing(): # _t is a magic variable that goes from 0 to 1 (and beyond) to get you the position of the mouse or the time slider over this element. 0 means at the left of this box, 1 means at the very right, 0.5 means in the middle print "...ongoing at time %f... " % _t
def stop(): print "... Stopping"
# start is called once, keepGoing is called while the box continues to run and finally stop is called just before the box isn't run any more _r = start, keepGoing, stop
# final note: you can make one of these boxes using the templating system (assuming you have the templates installed) # on the sheet hit 't' and select (or start typing) "tutorial.runningbox"

label= """this is a box with code in it, click to select it""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

label= """Just to the left of this text there's a red line that can be used to execute boxes by dragging it.

You might be able to grab the line from here, or you can pan over a bit using the middle mouse button (or a drag gesture on a laptop).""" width=300 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2()) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1

# this is another box you can run by option clicking on it, here's the code
def keepGoing(): print "...second box is ongoing at time %f... " % _t
_r = keepGoing

label= """if this begins to look like a time-line then that's because it is. Only it's a timeline with code in it.""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# you can just have any old code in here as well
print "any old print thing"

# _r can be set to other things. Of particular interest: a python generator very, very useful for animation
def aGenerator(): print "hello" yield 1 print "there" yield 1 print "everyone" yield 1 for n in range(0, 10): print "counting up %i " % n yield 1 for n in floatRange(0, 10, 20): print "counting down %f " % n yield 1 print "all done"
# watch that () _r = aGenerator()

label= """This is a time marker (you make them from the right click menu. The inspector palette can give these markers keyboard shortcuts and transition durations. This means that you can drive the red line around with the keyboard""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# while you can drag the red line around with the mouse, Field wouldn't be Field if you couldn't do it from code
# try executing this line by itself _self.timeSlider.frame.x=200
# then this one _self.timeSlider.frame.x=0
# if you right click on the red line and select "make time system drive ..." then you get more control over the line with code. Try these lines:
# just like the above _now.value=200
# animates a transition to position '0' over 200 frames _now.line=[200, 0]

label= """Pan over to the left to see one more box""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

label= """This is just a plain old box of code that you can option-click. But you can also try a few more things.

You can over above it and (with this window selected) use page-up and page-down to start and stop it.

You can select it and press the l (that's 'ell') key to get a 'local' slider.

You can click while holding down 's' to jump the red line to this point (or 'k' to drag the red line around a bit from wherever your mouse is).""" width=300 opacity=0.5 #--------------------------------------------- from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear() text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2()) text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label) text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity) _self.lines.add(text) _self.noFrame=1

label= """Keep panning right for more tutorial""" width=300 opacity=0.5
#---------------------------------------------
from java.awt import Font _self.lines.clear()
text = PLine().moveTo(0,0)(offsetFromSource=Vector2())
text(containsMultilineText=1) text(multilineWidth_v=width) text(text_v=label)
text(font_v=Font("Gill Sans", 0, 15)) text(totalOpacity=opacity)
_self.lines.add(text)
_self.noFrame=1

# this box needs the Processing plugin to be activated to function if (not _self.plugin_processingplugin_): print "this box needs the Processing plugin to be activated to function"
# here's a generator that goes from 'start' to 'stop' over a particular number of frames def bounce(start, stop, over): for n in range(0, over): value = start+(stop-start)*n/float(over) yield value
# to evaluate this generator press ctrl-command-/ bounce(1,2,100) # this will print the first 50 frames of any generator, just so you can see what it does
def applyToBackground(gen): for n in gen: p.background(255*n) yield 1
# if we run this box with _t set to this then we get an animated transition _r = applyToBackground(bounce(0, 1, 100))

field.core.ui.text.rulers.ExecutedAreas_.stringAtExecution: if (not _self.plugin_processingplugin_): print "this box needs the Processing plugin to be activated to function"
if (not _self.plugin_processingplugin_): print "this box needs the Processing plugin to be activated to function"
